segment.source: Creating a basic Windows Runtime component in C++ and calling it from JavaScript or C
segment.target: Creating a basic Windows Runtime component in C++ and calling it from JavaScript or C

segment.source: This walkthrough shows how to create a basic Windows Runtime Component DLL that's callable from JavaScript, C#, or Visual Basic.
segment.target: This walkthrough shows how to create a basic Windows Runtime Component DLL that's callable from JavaScript, C#, or Visual Basic.

segment.source: Walkthrough: Creating a basic Windows Runtime component in C++ and calling it from JavaScript or C
segment.target: Walkthrough: Creating a basic Windows Runtime component in C++ and calling it from JavaScript or C

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: This walkthrough shows how to create a basic Windows Runtime Component DLL that's callable from JavaScript, C#, or Visual Basic.
segment.target: This walkthrough shows how to create a basic Windows Runtime Component DLL that's callable from JavaScript, C#, or Visual Basic.

segment.source: Before you begin this walkthrough, make sure that you understand concepts such as the Abstract Binary Interface (ABI), ref classes, and the Visual C++ Component Extensions that make working with ref classes easier.
segment.target: Before you begin this walkthrough, make sure that you understand concepts such as the Abstract Binary Interface (ABI), ref classes, and the Visual C++ Component Extensions that make working with ref classes easier.

segment.source: For more information, see Creating Windows Runtime Components in C++ and Visual C++ Language Reference (C++/CX).
segment.target: For more information, see Creating Windows Runtime Components in C++ and Visual C++ Language Reference (C++/CX).

segment.source: Creating the C++ component DLL
segment.target: Creating the C++ component DLL

segment.source: In this example, we create the component project first, but you could create the JavaScript project first.
segment.target: In this example, we create the component project first, but you could create the JavaScript project first.

segment.source: The order doesn’t matter.
segment.target: The order doesn’t matter.

segment.source: Notice that the main class of the component contains examples of property and method definitions, and an event declaration.
segment.target: Notice that the main class of the component contains examples of property and method definitions, and an event declaration.

segment.source: These are provided just to show you how it's done.
segment.target: These are provided just to show you how it's done.

segment.source: They are not required, and in this example, we'll replace all of the generated code with our own code.
segment.target: They are not required, and in this example, we'll replace all of the generated code with our own code.

segment.source: To create the C++ component project
segment.target: To create the C++ component project

segment.source: On the Visual Studio menu bar, choose File, New, Project.
segment.target: On the Visual Studio menu bar, choose File, New, Project.

segment.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, expand Visual C++ and then select the node for Universal Windows apps.
segment.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, expand Visual C++ and then select the node for Universal Windows apps.

segment.source: In the center pane, select Windows Runtime Component and then name the project WinRT\_CPP.
segment.target: In the center pane, select Windows Runtime Component and then name the project WinRT\_CPP.

segment.source: Choose the OK button.
segment.target: Choose the OK button.

segment.source: To add an activatable class to the component
segment.target: To add an activatable class to the component

segment.source: An activatable class is one that client code can create by using a new expression (New in Visual Basic, or ref new in C++).
segment.target: An activatable class is one that client code can create by using a new expression (New in Visual Basic, or ref new in C++).

segment.source: In your component, you declare it as public ref class sealed.
segment.target: In your component, you declare it as public ref class sealed.

segment.source: In fact, the Class1.h and .cpp files already have a ref class.
segment.target: In fact, the Class1.h and .cpp files already have a ref class.

segment.source: You can change the name, but in this example we’ll use the default name—Class1.
segment.target: You can change the name, but in this example we’ll use the default name—Class1.

segment.source: You can define additional ref classes or regular classes in your component if they are required.
segment.target: You can define additional ref classes or regular classes in your component if they are required.

segment.source: For more information about ref classes, see Type System (C++/CX).
segment.target: For more information about ref classes, see Type System (C++/CX).

segment.source: Add these \#include directives to Class1.h:
segment.target: Add these \#include directives to Class1.h:

segment.source: Running the app
segment.target: Running the app

segment.source: Select either the C# project or JavaScript project as the startup project by opening the shortcut menu for the project node in Solution Explorer and choosing Set As Startup Project.
segment.target: Select either the C# project or JavaScript project as the startup project by opening the shortcut menu for the project node in Solution Explorer and choosing Set As Startup Project.

segment.source: Then press F5 to run with debugging, or Ctrl+F5 to run without debugging.
segment.target: Then press F5 to run with debugging, or Ctrl+F5 to run without debugging.

segment.source: Inspecting your component in Object Browser (optional)
segment.target: Inspecting your component in Object Browser (optional)

segment.source: In Object Browser, you can inspect all Windows Runtime types that are defined in .winmd files.
segment.target: In Object Browser, you can inspect all Windows Runtime types that are defined in .winmd files.

segment.source: This includes the types in the Platform namespace and the default namespace.
segment.target: This includes the types in the Platform namespace and the default namespace.

segment.source: However, because the types in the Platform::Collections namespace are defined in the header file collections.h, not in a winmd file, they don’t appear in Object Browser.
segment.target: However, because the types in the Platform::Collections namespace are defined in the header file collections.h, not in a winmd file, they don’t appear in Object Browser.

segment.source: To inspect a component
segment.target: To inspect a component

segment.source: On the menu bar, choose View, Object Browser (Ctrl+Alt+J).
segment.target: On the menu bar, choose View, Object Browser (Ctrl+Alt+J).

segment.source: In the left pane of the Object Browser, expand the WinRT\_CPP node to show the types and methods that are defined on your component.
segment.target: In the left pane of the Object Browser, expand the WinRT\_CPP node to show the types and methods that are defined on your component.

segment.source: Debugging tips
segment.target: Debugging tips

segment.source: For a better debugging experience, download the debugging symbols from the public Microsoft symbol servers:
segment.target: For a better debugging experience, download the debugging symbols from the public Microsoft symbol servers:

segment.source: To download debugging symbols
segment.target: To download debugging symbols

segment.source: On the menu bar, choose Tools, Options.
segment.target: On the menu bar, choose Tools, Options.

segment.source: In the Options dialog box, expand Debugging and select Symbols.
segment.target: In the Options dialog box, expand Debugging and select Symbols.

segment.source: Select Microsoft Symbol Servers and the choose the OK button.
segment.target: Select Microsoft Symbol Servers and the choose the OK button.

segment.source: It might take some time to download the symbols the first time.
segment.target: It might take some time to download the symbols the first time.

segment.source: For faster performance the next time you press F5, specify a local directory in which to cache the symbols.
segment.target: For faster performance the next time you press F5, specify a local directory in which to cache the symbols.

segment.source: When you debug a JavaScript solution that has a component DLL, you can set the debugger to enable either stepping through script or stepping through native code in the component, but not both at the same time.
segment.target: When you debug a JavaScript solution that has a component DLL, you can set the debugger to enable either stepping through script or stepping through native code in the component, but not both at the same time.

segment.source: To change the setting, open the shortcut menu for the JavaScript project node in Solution Explorer and choose Properties, Debugging, Debugger Type.
segment.target: To change the setting, open the shortcut menu for the JavaScript project node in Solution Explorer and choose Properties, Debugging, Debugger Type.

segment.source: Be sure to select appropriate capabilities in the package designer.
segment.target: Be sure to select appropriate capabilities in the package designer.

segment.source: You can open the package designer by opening the Package.appxmanifest file.
segment.target: You can open the package designer by opening the Package.appxmanifest file.

segment.source: For example, if you are attempting to programmatically access files in the Pictures folder, be sure to select the Pictures Library check box in the Capabilities pane of the package designer.
segment.target: For example, if you are attempting to programmatically access files in the Pictures folder, be sure to select the Pictures Library check box in the Capabilities pane of the package designer.

segment.source: If your JavaScript code doesn't recognize the public properties or methods in the component, make sure that in JavaScript you are using camel casing.
segment.target: If your JavaScript code doesn't recognize the public properties or methods in the component, make sure that in JavaScript you are using camel casing.

segment.source: For example, the C++ method must be referenced as in JavaScript.
segment.target: For example, the C++ method must be referenced as in JavaScript.

segment.source: If you remove a C++ Windows Runtime Component project from a solution, you must also manually remove the project reference from the JavaScript project.
segment.target: If you remove a C++ Windows Runtime Component project from a solution, you must also manually remove the project reference from the JavaScript project.

segment.source: Failure to do so prevents subsequent debug or build operations.
segment.target: Failure to do so prevents subsequent debug or build operations.

segment.source: If necessary, you can then add an assembly reference to the DLL.
segment.target: If necessary, you can then add an assembly reference to the DLL.

segment.target: Related topics
